title: Kansas City Chiefs help cancer survivors
text:
KANSAS CITY, MO (KCTV) - Every year, the Kansas City Chiefs join other NFL players to support October's National Breast Cancer Awareness Month.
As a new mom and Chiefs cheerleader, Brandy Reed was not ready to hear the words many of us dread:  "You have breast cancer".
“He was four months old when I was diagnosed,” she said. “Obviously, as a new mother, that was the last news I wanted to hear.”
Diagnosed at age 29, she had no clue what was coming next. 
“It’s very hard to lose your hair, not have control of your facial features as far as losing your eyelashes and eyebrows. And also what comes along with chemotherapy is the weight gain. That was difficult for me,” Reed said.
Reed joined the Chiefs defensive backs, the University of Kansas Hospital and the American Cancer Society Tuesday for the third annual luncheon at Arrowhead Stadium to learn beauty techniques specifically designed for cancer patients.
Even tough guys like Chiefs safety Eric Berry struggle with the physical side effects that come with treatment.  
“The biggest thing that really changed my appearance was not having eyebrows...It was something simple, but you just look in mirror and try to figure out what's going on,” he said.
About eight months after being diagnosed with lymphoma, Berry was cleared medically to practice with the Chiefs. He proves that perseverance with treatment can pay off.
“At end of day, you have to understand that you are still the same person regardless of how you look or feel,” he said.
Reed had her last chemo treatment two days before her son’s second birthday.
